advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 464 - 6128 PERIPHERALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From top left to bottom right:<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 6128<br> - Joystick with joystick adaptor<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 464<br> - Disc drive with interface and CP/M for CPC 464<br> - Speech synthesizer and stereo amplifier<br> - Additional disc drive<br> - Light pen with graphics software<br> - RS232 interface<br> - DMP 2000 dot printer</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPAN ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>It's an advert for both the YIS-503 and YIS-303 which were quite similar except for the keyboard and the memory size...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BYTE SHOPPER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Spring 1978 issue of Byte shopper guide</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-503 is a YIS-303 with more memory (32 kb) and a proper keyboard.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing is very simple with the AIM65 from Rockwell"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUASAR AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8 KB quasar system with the 4 color plotter/printer interface.<br><br> The small picture shows a complete system with memory expansion, modem and video interfaces.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad is unique in that it features professional actors and IMSAI employees. <p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.guiguy.com/Schiff/" target="_blank">www.guiguy.com/Schiff/</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRIDGE COMPUTER VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1982, the <b>Bridge Computer Company</b> (Newton, MASS) sold a Z80 software developper system with the InterSystems mainframe, CP/M 2.2 operating system and various optional programming languages.The configuration was:<br><br> - 6 Mhz. Z80-B CPU with memory management<br> - 256 KB RAM expandable to 1 MB<br> - Two 8" or 5.25" F.D. drives, single or double sided<br> - Optional 5" or 8" hard disk, up to 40 MB<br> - Televideo serial video terminal. <br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Does this sound too good to be true? Just fill your tank with the BRIDGE 3C formula for SPEED and shift into 'overdrive' with your bridge 3C Compiler System. Leave the other behind, let us provide you with the fuel for higher productivity...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GOLDSTAR 3DO MODEL ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://members.aol.com/djswaggle/3doad.html" target="_blank">3DO ads</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JUNE 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1986, the Alphatronic PC was bargained in many broker shops for a low price.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>This promotional picture was used to emphasize the programming assets of the TO-7/70 : Microsoft Basic v5, Microsoft assembler and SOLI Logo. They want to make us believe that architects used TO-7/70 ! <br><br> As usual there are no cables shown... The arm looks weird, lifeless... did they cut it to take the picture more easily ?! or is the woman completely laid down on the table ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I clicked"... </blockquote>

computer.description:
Although the HP-9825 was presented by HP as a desktop calculator with some computer features, it was really a desktop computer, in fact the first all-in-one computer everyone could use without being a computers guru.
This system was lauched quite at the same time as the first personal systems (Altair 8800, Imsai 8080), however, its concepts and features were much more advanced but its price was about ten times the one of an Imsai, it thus wasn't intended to hobbyists market.
Inside the portable case, one found: ? a full HP 16-bit CPU called 5061 with math coprocessor, ? 8 KB to 32 KB of RAM, ? HPL, an advanced high-level programming language close to BASIC, ? a complete standard low-profile keyboard, ? a 32 character alphanumeric LED display, ? a built-in 16 column thermal printer, ? a magnetic DC-100 cartridge tape drive.
Furthermore, four ROM-pack housings allowed to extand HPL capabilities or run specialized software, and three expansion slots provided communication capabilities with any type of peripherals: measuring instruments, printers, plotters, mass storage devices. The expansions operating system was developed by Joe Beyers who will become later Vice President of HP Computer Systems Business.
Two additional versions of the 9825 were manufactured, the 9825S included a set of ROM packs and the 9825B featured a true typewriter keyboard instead of the low-profile version. _______________________
computer.keyboard: 98 keys with 18 fuction keys, numeric and cursor keypads
computer.name: HP-9825
computer.ports: 4 x ROM pack, 3 x expansion slots

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>The DC-100 cartridge drive is at the left side of the LED display, the thermal printer at the right.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 4 ROM-PACKS</strong></font><br><blockquote>• String ADV. Programming - added advanced string commands to the HPL language<br> • Plotter<br> • GEN I/O, Extended I/O<br> • Systems Programming</blockquote>

computer.sound: Simple beep through a built-in tiny speaker
